metadata.subject: ELA
metadata.domainName: Edexcel IGCSE English Language IG Stage 2

questions.text: Critical evaluation of a text requires examining evidence, argument structure, and writer bias.
questions.subject: ELA

questions.text: Which question best assesses argument validity?

choices: Does the evidence logically support the conclusion?
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Does the evidence logically support the conclusion?

questions.subject: ELA

questions.text: Source reliability can be evaluated by checking expertise, bias, and corroboration.

questions.text: Match each source evaluation criterion to its description.

questions.text: Analyzing perspective involves understanding how viewpoint shapes representation.
questions.subject: ELA

questions.text: Which indicates bias in a text?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: One-sided language and omitted counterarguments

questions.subject: ELA

questions.text: Arrange these argument strengths from weakest to strongest.

questions.text: Comparing viewpoints across texts reveals different perspectives on the same topic.
questions.subject: ELA

questions.text: Which logical fallacy involves attacking the person rather than the argument?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Ad hominem

questions.subject: ELA

questions.text: Match each logical fallacy to its definition.

rightItems: Presenting only two options when more exist
Claiming one event will lead to extreme consequences
Misrepresenting an argument to attack it

questions.text: Critical reading requires questioning assumptions and examining evidence quality.
questions.subject: ELA

questions.text: Which best describes synthesizing multiple sources?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Combining information to create new understanding

questions.text: Arrange these critical reading strategies in order of depth.

questions.text: Which question evaluates evidence quality?

choices: Is this evidence recent, relevant, and reliable?
Is there a lot of evidence?
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Is this evidence recent, relevant, and reliable?

questions.text: Implicit bias can be detected through language choices and omissions.

questions.text: Arrange these source types by typical reliability for academic purposes.

questions.text: Which statement about comparing texts is correct?

choices: Examine both similarities and differences in approach and effect
Only compare texts of the same length
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Examine both similarities and differences in approach and effect

questions.subject: ELA

questions.text: Match each comparison focus to what it reveals.

rightItems: Different word choices and their effects

questions.text: Effective evaluation considers both strengths and limitations of a text.
questions.subject: ELA

questions.text: Which approach best identifies propaganda techniques?

choices: Accept all claims at face value
Analyze emotional manipulation, loaded language, and logical fallacies
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Analyze emotional manipulation, loaded language, and logical fallacies

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Relevant evidence with logical reasoning

questions.text: Which concluding strategy is most effective?

choices: That's all I have to say.
Synthesizing evidence to reinforce thesis with a call to action or broader implication.
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Synthesizing evidence to reinforce thesis with a call to action or broader implication.

questions.text: Which demonstrates sophisticated comparative analysis?

choices: Text A is better than Text B.
While both texts explore loss, A's fragmented structure creates immediacy whereas B's linear narrative allows reflection.
Text A and Text B are different.
questionOptions.correctAnswer: While both texts explore loss, A's fragmented structure creates immediacy whereas B's linear narrative allows reflection.
